comment._content: What a great photo. I wonder if Dr, Bradfield is amongst those standing on the arch?

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: There is a nice series of photos showing the progress of this demolition: trove.nla.gov.au/picture/result?q=demolish+princes+street... An interesting letter giving some hsitorical background of the arch(es): nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16830131 And a Sydney Morning Herald article from 22/08/1932 mentioning the demolition: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16799511 This photo shows some of the mass of old bridge stonework already removed above the arch: investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... Nice little essay about the arches: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16740442

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] That is interesting research.  It seems the Princes Street bridge was comprised of two separate arches, built years apart.  Hence the men were relatively safe to stand on the other half. 

Are we looking east or west ?  That looks a bit like the Garrison Church top right, in which case looking west.  Or not?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Here's an even better OH&S arch moment! Fearless Joe Dobson - Demolishing Hoffnung's building, Pitt Street, Sydney by Ernie Bowen (15/11/1939) [SLNSW: hood_19948, hood_19949] "... the crowd in Pitt Street was good. Some crowds wouldn't give you a cheer if you tore the building down with your teeth. But this crowd gave you a clap when you did a good brick. In fact, I don't think I've ever had a better crowd." - Joe Dobson interviewed in Daily News, 16 November 1939. (see Sydney Exposures by Alan Davies, Sydney : State Library of NSW, 1991, p. 50.) And yes, looking west. That is the Garrison Church as you surmised. The other photographs in the series that [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13267298@N00] BobMeade linked make it clearer.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Ha ha! Thanks for the westerly confirmation, which means the date stone was found at left of frame, on the east side. The other (west) side of the Princes St bridge (built earlier, c.1853) had completely different stonework, chevron like a mouth with teeth - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5061232836/] Each of the three bridges seems to have date stones. Gloucester Street 1882(?) - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4625663816/] And this wonderful Henry King photo shows a date stone on the Cumberland Street bridge which I cannot quite read - HELP! - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362705933/] from.ph/30772 Confused? So was I.
